Verizon Super cookie and many of you may be aware that a few years ago

the the browsing activities of its subscribers this was concerning to the

this technology I think it's probably helpful to just to walk through how Verizon intended for this business model
to work step one is a subscribers browser or app sends HTTP requests this
is normal I mean all of our phones do this anytime that we browse the web or
or use an app that those requests go through Verizon which would then insert
a unique identifier as an additional HTTP request header effectively allowing
Verizon or anyone with access to the header to know uniquely who the origin
of this traffic came from that information is then as the consumer or
subscriber visits various websites it's then passed on through to a third
party advertising exchange which receives the header information and then
forwards it on to data brokers that may be participating in that exchange those
data brokers who now are able to see the header along information will then use
that to match it with data from Verizon it may be demographic data such as it's
a male between the ages of 20 and 30 it may be geolocation information that
Verizon just provides about the header but now as a data broker you have the ability to not only know basic general
demographic information but also know particularly where this demographic is is is browsing on the web that
information is then used to put together to target advertisements directly to
consumers and of course at the end of the day everybody gets a little bit of a little bit of money Verizon get some
compensation the the data brokers the exchanges make a little money as well as
the ads are served we learned about this
through both complaints as well as a number of news articles that came out
about the super cookies and here was our concern from the in the enforcement
Bureau Verizon began its you idh program in around December of 2012 but it
actually didn't tell anyone about it for nearly two years until October of 2014
during during during the midst of our investigation it's a little troubling to
think that a company was injecting information that can be used for
targeted ad vert izing to all its millions of customers without telling any of them
about it for for almost two years when they did finally decide to disclose
information about the program Verizon claimed that the UI DHS were
unlikely to be used other than his Verizon had intended as part of its advertising program but what actually
turned out is we found that in fact at least one of Verizon's own partners a
company called turn was was at least one that was public at least one of those
partners used UI DHS to resurrect tracking cookies effectively
circumventing browser and operating system privacy protection that is consumers have the ability in their in
their browser for example to delete a cookie right and we thought that was a
way to protect privacy what the UI D H does is it allows the network level to begin to reassociate even if you delete
the cookie if it comes back and you still have the header traffic you can take the information you had on the prior cookie because it's the same
header and connect the two together effectively mitigating the effect of
deletions of cookies we were also troubled that Verizon not only inserted
the UID H into its own subscribers traffic but into the traffic of non
Verizon customers who may have been roaming on the Verizon network as well so that they were able to see where they
were where they were browsing and potentially target ads to them as well
we ended up happily settling this case earlier this year we find Verizon a
modest fine I would say of one point three five million dollars but the important point about this was not the

going to be required to obtain opt-in consent before injecting UID h's into 80
HTTP requests to third-party websites this was in addition to actually informing its customers that it was
actually using this program but it was important that those consumers opt into the program
that they not be opted in by Verizon and not told about it but that they have the ability to make a choice before this
information was provided to third-party websites we also required Verizon to
offer a choice to entirely withdraw from the You idh program if you wanted to
have nothing nothing to do with it as a Verizon customer and we prohibited them
from injecting the UI D H into MVNO traffic really good some we think for
for all Verizon consumers as well as from promoting you know privacy

the next cases that I want to talk about are a couple of data breaches that we've

atheon t like like many companies in the united states operates call centers

submit unlock request for over two hundred and eighty thousand AT&T customers as we investigated this case

40 customer service reps in these call centers in Colombia and the Philippines

importantly we required better monitoring of what's going on in the call centers better training for the the

Geordie called up a customer service representative at Cox and said hey this

enter your login information your ID your password and of course evil Jordy
was on the other side of the website he suddenly had their login and password at
this time Cox did not require multi-factor authentication and therefore evil Jordy was able to have
all of the same access that a customer service representative had at this time that was access to the personal
information of all of Cox's 6 million or so subscribers evil Jordy then went into
went into the Cox database and he he targeted a number of customers he locked

and we ended up settling this case it was for $600,000 as a fine but more
importantly we wanted to make sure that there was multi-factor authentication in place we wanted to make sure there was
training that was put in place and I tell you about these cases at a conference like blackhat because the
reality is that is the vast majority of data breaches that we see they look like
this they look like pretexting they look like employees who are on the take or who
were not being monitored they're not all intrusions my outsiders who are finding
a sophisticated way to get around the IT architecture this is the reality and so
as we as we look at the the vendors that are here as we think about how to

flow from probing the network than authenticating to the network and then
associating with the network and finally application traffic can flow back and forth between your device in the Wi-Fi

and the Wi-Fi that's installed in a certain certain place that's important competition and if the hotspot is
